subsection_content:
Acute pyelonephritis is an acute infection, so symptoms usually appear within 2 days after the bacteria attack. Typical onset symptoms include:
High fever above 38.9°C; Pain in the abdomen, back, side or groin; Painful or burning urination, urgency, frequent urination; Cloudy urine, pus or blood in the urine, urine may have a fishy odor
Other symptoms may include:
Colds or chills, nausea, vomiting; Pain in the back ribs on one side or both sides, severe pain can spread to the bladder and external genitals.; The large kidneys can be felt, pressing on them causes a sharp pain for the patient.
However, there are currently many statistics showing that up to 20% of patients do not have bladder symptoms (painful urination, frequent urination, pus in urine, etc.), and some patients do not have fever. In addition, some studies on pyelonephritis also clearly show that the disease appears but the patient does not have pain. Clinical manifestations and severity of the disease vary widely.
Severe disease tends to attack people with weakened immune systems, urinary tract obstruction, pregnant women and people over 65 years old.
